support_summary: TDP-43 is a key component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway for DNA double-strand break repair. It acts as a scaffold to recruit the XRCC4/DNA Ligase 4 complex to sites of DNA damage.

functions.cellular_process: TDP-43 is a critical component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway for repairing DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). It is recruited to sites of DNA damage.
functions.effect_description: TDP-43 acts as a scaffold to recruit the XRCC4/DNA Ligase 4 complex to the site of the break. This recruitment is essential for the final, rate-limiting step of ligating the broken DNA ends. Loss of nuclear TDP-43 impairs this process, leading to the accumulation of DNA damage.
biological_consequence: DNA double-strand break → TDP-43 recruitment to damage site → Scaffolding and recruitment of XRCC4/Ligase 4 complex → Efficient NHEJ repair → Maintenance of genomic stability
specific_effects: Loss of nuclear TDP-43 function impairs the recruitment of the XRCC4-DNA ligase 4 complex to DSB sites.
TDP-43 depletion leads to reduced NHEJ efficiency and an accumulation of unrepaired DSBs.
In ALS, TDP-43 mislocalization may trap the XRCC4/Ligase 4 complex in the cytoplasm, preventing its nuclear function.
